content:
You cannot have done what you said, because an account in Thunderbird cannot be changed from POP to IMAP or vice versa. You must have set up an entirely different account using different mail servers. I'd love to know what makes you think you would be able to access the mail stored on the old mail server using the setup for the new mail server…

The old account should still be present in Thunderbird if you didn't remove it, but the old email provider may not allow you to access it anymore after having switched to another email provider even if you try to do so using the old account settings…

Depending on what you did (which cannot be what you say you did), though, the mail stored locally on your computer by Thunderbird may still be lurking around somewhere within your profile folder and you may be able to get it back.

The following article explains what's a profile and how to locate the profile folder in the filesystem: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

For each account in Thunderbird, there is an account folder named after the incoming mail server in the profile folder, either within Mail if the account is POP, or within ImapMail if the account is IMAP. Check whether you may find a folder for what would have been your old email account, to get an idea of whether your mail may still be there, and post back with the results.
creator: DavidGG

creator: ginger213

content:
I did what I said.

No, you didn't, because what you said is IMPOSSIBLE. Either you (1) changed mail servers, but the type of account (POP/IMAP) remained the same, or (2) you did set up a new account in Thunderbird, which is the ONLY way you can change from POP to IMAP or vice versa…

assumed the old emails would remain locally on my computer

And they would if the old account was POP as you said, but everything you're saying would seem to indicate the old account was IMAP as well, not POP, in which case yeah, all your mail stored locally on the computer for that account would be gone after Thunderbird synchronised with the new server…

I guess I can go back to my web host's settings temporarily until I can somehow back them up to my pc. Will that work?

If the account does still exist on the old host and you're allowed to access it, yes. You could then create folders under Local Folders, at the bottom of the list of accounts in the folder pane in Thunderbird, to store and organise your mail locally on your computer there however you wish, independently of any mail account you may have.
creator: DavidGG

content: The message is being relayed by Thunderbird, but it is originating with your providers outgoing mail server. Who provides your email address? Have you contacted them? if so, with what result?

content:
The first question that becomes obvious is are these IMAP or POP retrieved mails?

Plus addressing in some instances sees the emails placed in special folders on the server, so differences occur depending on the way the account is configured with regard to IMAP and POP and folder subscriptions.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
With my old email

What do you mean your "old email"? If you changed your email provider, that would explain not being able to receive those messages at the server, because not all mail servers support that feature, but if your messages are there on the server and you can see them with some other mail client, then you should be able to see them in Thunderbird too. Thunderbird doesn't care what address the message was sent to, just whether it's on the server or not…

content:
really Thunderbird as a mail client downloads mail. It can filter mail, and delete using a filter, but first it has to fetch the email so it can be filtered.

If you insist on doing it server side, look at a server rule, perhaps block the sender using yahoos facilities for that (ATT mail addresses are just yahoo). You could also look as spam filtering products like mailwasher.

content: I'm surprised you figured how to do it, because you really can't. Gmail labels are mapped to folders on the IMAP server, but they're not the same thing, because a message can have multiple labels in Gmail, but be in a single folder in IMAP. In order to apply a Gmail label to a message without removing any other labels it may have, you would have to copy the message to the IMAP folder corresponding to that label. But that copy would be treated as a different message from the original in the mail client, not as a message that's in multiple folders at the same time…

content:
Možnosti: 1. Niekto kto má prístup k tomuto účtu odstránil všetky správy. - v Thunderbirde preverte priečinok KOŠ a či tam náhodou nie sú tie odstránené správy. 2. Niekto kto má prístup k tomuto účtu nastavil nejaký FILTER tak, aby správy "staršie ako..." boli odstránené. - v Thunderbirde preverte priečinok KOŠ a či tam náhodou nie sú tie odstránené správy. 3. Niekto kto má prístup k tomuto účtu asi tie správy ARCHÍVOVAL - preverte či je vytvorený priečinok ARCHÍVY a či tam náhodou nie sú 4. Je možné, že už je preplnený priečinok "Doručená pošta" a možno aj "Odoslaná pošta", kde je Thunderbirdom stanovený maximálny objem 4GB (rovnako ako aj pre každý samostatný priečinok). Kliknite na priečinok "Doručená pošta" pravým tlačidlom myši, vyberte "Vlastnosti" a preverte akú veľkosť na disku zaberá. Limit veľkosti zložky je detailnejšie vysvetlený tuná: http://kb.mozillazine.org/Limits_%28Thunderbird%29#Folders_and_messages.

POZOR: Pokiaľ v Thunderbirde odstránite e-mail, tak sa v skutočnosti iba označí ako odstránený, ale fyzicky zostane. Jeho fyzické odstránenie sa vykoná až použitím voľby "Údržba priečinkov“. Takže zatiaľ opatrne s "Údržbou priečinkov“!

content:
I guess you mean the middle section of the Thunderbird main window in "Vertical" view. This pane in the middle is named "thread pane". You can give it a background colour using some CSS code in a userChrome.css file in the TB profile.

When I use the following CSS code in my userChrome.css file

.tree-table { background-color: lavender !important; }

the background of the thread tree will look like this (image 1, I am using "Classic" view )

If I use the following CSS codes

.tree-table { background-color: azure !important; } #threadTree tr:nth-child(2n) { background-image: linear-gradient(rgba(0,0,0,.06), rgba(0,0,0,.06)) }

they will add a zebra stripe effect to the thread pane as it was the standard in earlier TB (Mac) versions (Image 2)

If you are interested in one or both colour schemes I'll give your more details concerning the userChrome.css file in Thunderbird profile.

creator: DavidGG

content:
You need to know what the server settings are supposed to be and then set up the account accordingly. Which is your email provider? If you post a screenshot of your outgoing (SMTP) server settings, we may verify they're correct.

Read the following article in the meantime to see possible causes of the problem: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages

In particular, if you're using a VPN, disable it and see whether that makes the problem go away. If it does, check whether your VPN has an option called split tunneling which would allow you to let Thunderbird bypass the VPN.
creator: DavidGG
